Comment: A mini-tournament game, I'm playing black and I'm tired of the Sicilian so I meet white in the center, daring him to play my favorite opening. This is the 4th game I've annotated this evening, and I played black in all of them. Sometimes it seems like I play black 80% of the time, though my statistics don't corroborate that.

A mini-tournament game, I'm playing black and I'm tired of the Sicilian so I meet white in the center, daring him to play my favorite opening. This is the 4th game I've annotated this evening, and I played black in all of them. Sometimes it seems like I play black 80% of the time, though my statistics don't corroborate that.

And he did. The Ruy Lopez. But what is this? As much as I have played the Spanish game, I don't recall anyone playing 3. ... g6 against me. However, the GK DB gives it good marks, so I thought I'd give it a whirl. Take your pick, it's either called the Smyslov Defense, Fianchetto Defense, or Barnes Defense. Evidently it can give white the advantage and doesn't get played much at the highest level. Oh well, I'm far from the highest level, so like Robert Frost, I choose the defense less traveled.

Threatening a simple back rank checkmate with 21. ... Qf1+ 22. Rxf1 Rxf1#, but also threatening the pawn on b2.
Threatening a simple back rank checkmate with 21. ... Qf1+ 22. Rxf1 Rxf1#, but also threatening the pawn on b2.

Oops. 21. g3??? was a blunder that will cost white the game. I initially saw the fork that wins the rook, but then when I entered the conditional moves, I kept going and very quickly found that black has a 6-move forced checkmate beginning with 21. Qf3+, so I entered the conditional moves and announced the mate in 6 in the game. I am a bit embarrassed to admit I did not actually see the mate until I was entering the simple conditional move to fork the white rook.

White's in deep now. 23. Qf1 allows 23. ... Qxf1#. But after 23. Kg2, black plays 23. ... Qf3+ 24. Kg1 Qf2+ 25. Kh1 Qe1+ 26. Kg2 Rf2#. So it's mate either way. White chose to resign.
